comment._content: Flora Whitney was born in 1897, according to this article about her mother: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gertrude_Vanderbilt_Whitney She was 3 years older than Tommy Hitchcock, which seems about right looking at the photo.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Flora Payne Whitney (1897 - 1985) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flora_Payne_Whitney I agree that Miss Whitney looks to be about three years older than young Hitchcock. Do you suppose they would have been at the Steeplechase races without their parents? No way. I've had a look at the uncompressed Tiff version of this photograph downloaded from the persistent URL, and Hitchcock Jr. is holding a card that has a headline at the top "RACING" and lower down "Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association Belmont Park Terminal ..." Therefore, I believe this photograph was almost certainly taken at the Steeplechase meeting held on May 4, 1912. The New York Times report of the following day is here: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990DE5DC153CE633A... and amongst the Society notables in the crowd of 4,000 people were Mr. and Mrs. Payne Whitney, and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock.

comment._content: lifeasdaddy:  Yes, your new date seems likely.  We'll add the new information to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 80157956@N07
comment._content: Flora Whitney was later engaged to Quentin Roosevelt, the son of President Theodore Roosevelt. Both Quentin Roosevelt and Tommy Hitchcock Jr. became fighter pilots in World War I and were shot down by the Germans. Quentin Roosevelt was killed, Hitchcock was captured but escaped. Hitchcock also ended up getting killed flying a fighter plane decades later when he was the Army Air Force attache to the US Embassy in London during World War II when he was test-flying a P-51 Mustang, the development of which he was heavily involved in.
